awd_titl_txt: CAREER:    Trust and Privacy Management for Online Social Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Trust and Privacy Management for Online Social Networks

Online social networks greatly expand the scale of people's social connections, and have the potential to become an open computing platform, where new services can be quickly offered and propagated. Mechanisms for trust management and privacy protection are integral to the future success of online social networks. A trustworthy social network should allow users to flexibly control who can access their social information and to what extend. Online social networks also broaden the scope and scale of social science. Privacy issues arise naturally when the data of online social networks are shared for research and other purposes. 

This project develops theoretical and practical techniques for the management of trust and privacy for online social networks. One central goal is to look into the future of online social networks and develop techniques that are not only suitable for today?s social networks but for the future open computing platform built on top of them. In particular, this project focuses on flexible trust models for social networks, privacy preserving feedback issuing and management, and graph anonymization for the sharing of social network data. The developed techniques directly help the secure development and deployment of a wide range of new types of services that are well beyond the realm of traditional online services. This project also develops educational materials to improve undergraduate students? understanding and interests in computer science and attract more students to enroll in computer science degrees.

por.por_cntn:
Online social networks greatly expand the scope of Internet and profoundly change the way individuals and organizations communicate, collaborate, entertain and conduct business.  The project was established to systematically address trust and privacy issues in online social networks. The major outcomes are summarized as follows.

(1) Composite trust model for social networks: Trust is critical in social networks where people often can join freely and interact possibly without prior knowledge of each other. It is important to have trust models that capture different aspects for trust establishment in such decentralized environment. This project designed a formal and unified trust model that incorporate both vertical and horizontal trust. Vertical trust refers to that derived from organization hierarchies (e.g., trust of a government agency) while horizontal trust is about trust relationships between equal parties (e.g., friends and colleagues). The project shows that both types of trust can be represented through role-based relationships. The trust model developed in the project also allows flexible composition of different types of trust, which can be used to accurately capture complex trust relationships in social networks.

(2) There is a great need for social network to be shared for business as well as research purposes. However, such data sharing must ensure sufficient protection of individual's private information. This project developed advanced techniques to anonymize social network data. Our first outcome is an anonymization scheme for bipartite graphs. Different from traditional anonymization techniques targeting at tabular data, The developed scheme focuses on anonymizing graph structures through safe grouping, which prevents inference of private information, even if an attacker obtains significant knowledge of an individual's social relationship. 

(3) This project further developed privacy-preserving data sharing scheme based on the concept of differential privacy, which ensures that even if adversaries obtain very strong background knowledge, the output of a computation over sensitive data does not reveal whether an individual's private information is used in the computation. The first problem addressed in the project is to publish spatial data while satisfying differential privacy. We designed a privacy-preserving indexing scheme which partitions a multi-dimension space, so that spatial queries can be answered accurately. 

(4) The project further extends its scope to investigate appropriate tradeoff between privacy and utility, in particular in a pragmatic setting. We have designed a differentially private algorithm for social recommendation systems. Different from prior work which assumes all information in a recommendation system to be sensitive (and thus resulting in poor utility when achieving differential privacy), we recognize that many social relationships tend to be less sensitive while user-product relationship (e.g., who watches which video or buys what medicine) is much more sensitive. Taking advantage of such observations, we developed a practical differentially private social recommendation system which offers accurate recommendation while guaranteeing differential privacy.

(5) Following the above theme, we further extend the concept of differential privacy to accommodate the observation that oftentimes people have different levels of concerns of privacy. Offering the same level of protection is often not necessary and harmful for utility. We therefore proposed and formalize the concept of personalized differential privacy. We further designed general techniques to achieve personalized privacy. We show through experiments that personalized differential privacy greatly improves the utility of anonymized data, which is important for data sharing in practice.
